Introduction

Staphylococcus-associated glomerulonephritis (SAGN) involves immune-mediated kidney injury triggered by staphylococcal infections, typically with Staphylococcus aureus.  It is primarily seen in adults, in contrast to poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is more commonly seen in children (although it is occasionally seen in adults).  SAGN occurs during infection or shortly after infection resolution, whereas PSGN arises several weeks following infection.  Other causes of infection-related glomerulonephritis (GN)—including endocarditis-associated GN and GN due to nonbacterial infections (eg, hepatitis C virus infection)—are discussed in separate articles.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



SAGN arises when antibodies form immune complexes with staphylococcal bacterial antigens, depositing in glomeruli and activating the complement cascade (primarily the alternative pathway).  This triggers inflammation, leukocyte infiltration, and glomerular injury.  SAGN occurs concurrently with active infection from a variety of sources, most commonly cellulitis, osteomyelitis, and pneumonia.  Risk factors include diabetes mellitus, cirrhosis, heavy alcohol use, and immunosuppression (eg, HIV, chemotherapy), all of which increase the risk for bacterial infections.

Clinical presentation



SAGN and PSGN differ in both patient demographics and timeline of infection:



  • SAGN:  More common in adults, occurring concurrently with active infection (usually from S aureus) with a variety of infectious sources (eg, cellulitis, osteomyelitis, pneumonia).
  • PSGN:  More common in children, occurring several weeks after group A Streptococcus infection (eg, erysipelas, pharyngitis).


In SAGN, systemic signs of infection, including fever, malaise, and localized symptoms (eg, erythema, ulceration, productive cough), are often present.  As with other types of GN, nephritic syndrome, including hematuria (gross or microscopic), proteinuria, hypertension, and acute kidney injury, is usually present.  Occasionally, proteinuria exceeds 3.5 g/day (ie, nephrotic range), resulting in mixed nephrotic-nephritic syndrome.



Diagnosis



SAGN should be suspected in adults with signs of GN (eg, hematuria, proteinuria, elevated serum creatinine) alongside a confirmed or suspected concurrent or recent staphylococcal infection.

Laboratory testing



A key laboratory clue is low serum complement, particularly low serum C3, reflecting complement consumption from an immune complex–mediated process (

).  However, hypocomplementemia is not universally present.  Other forms of GN, including the following conditions (with some associated findings), should be excluded:



  • Lupus nephritis:  Antinuclear antibodies and anti–double stranded DNA autoantibodies.
  • Goodpasture disease:  Antiglomerular basement membrane antibodies.
  • Viral and malignancy:  Hepatitis B/C and HIV antibodies, serum cryoglobulins, and protein electrophoresis showing free light chains.

Kidney biopsy



Diagnosis often requires kidney biopsy for confirmation and for ruling out other causes of hypocomplementemic GN.  However, biopsy can be deferred if GN coincides temporally with a confirmed active S aureus infection.  Histologic findings include:



  • Light microscopy:  Diffuse endocapillary proliferation with neutrophils; crescentic or membranoproliferative patterns may occur.
  • Immunofluorescence:  Dominant C3 with or without IgA/IgG deposits (starry sky or garland patterns).  IgA dominance distinguishes SAGN from poststreptococcal GN.
  • Electron microscopy:  Subepithelial hump-like deposits, although these overlap with C3 GN.


Definitive diagnosis hinges on clinical improvement after infection clearance, although residual renal dysfunction may persist.

Management



Treatment is dependent on infection eradication with culture-guided antibiotics.  Supportive care includes loop diuretics for edema, ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers for proteinuria to treat hypertension, and, in severe cases, dialysis.  Immunosuppression is generally avoided.

Summary



Staphylococcus-associated glomerulonephritis is an immune-mediated kidney injury triggered primarily by Staphylococcus aureus infection.  Unlike poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, which typically affects children after infection resolution, Staphylococcus-associated glomerulonephritis occurs mainly in adults during infection or soon after resolution (eg, cellulitis, osteomyelitis, pneumonia).  Pathogenesis involves immune complex deposition in glomeruli, complement activation, inflammation, and glomerular injury.  Clinical features include nephritic syndrome with hematuria, proteinuria, hypertension, and acute kidney injury.  Diagnosis is suggested by concurrent staphylococcal infection, hypocomplementemia (particularly low C3), and characteristic biopsy findings.  Management focuses on treating the underlying infection and using supportive measures, and immunosuppression is generally avoided.
